_**Rise of the Planet of the Apes**_ is a 2011 American [science fiction
film](/wiki/Science_fiction_film "Science fiction film") directed by [Rupert
Wyatt](/wiki/Rupert_Wyatt "Rupert Wyatt") and starring [James
Franco](/wiki/James_Franco "James Franco"), [Freida Pinto](/wiki/Freida_Pinto
"Freida Pinto"), [John Lithgow](/wiki/John_Lithgow "John Lithgow"), [Brian
Cox](/wiki/Brian_Cox_\(actor\) "Brian Cox \(actor\)"), [Tom
Felton](/wiki/Tom_Felton "Tom Felton"), [David Oyelowo](/wiki/David_Oyelowo
"David Oyelowo"), and [Andy Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis "Andy Serkis"). Written
by [Rick Jaffa and Amanda Silver](/wiki/Rick_Jaffa_and_Amanda_Silver "Rick
Jaffa and Amanda Silver"), it is [20th Century Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox
"20th Century Fox")'s [reboot](/wiki/Reboot_\(fiction\) "Reboot \(fiction\)")
of the _[Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes "Planet of the Apes")_
series, intended to act as an [origin story](/wiki/Origin_story "Origin
story") for a new series of films.[6] Its premise is similar to the fourth
film in the original series, _[Conquest of the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Conquest_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Conquest of the Planet of the
Apes")_ (1972), but it is not a direct [remake](/wiki/Remake "Remake") of that
film.

_Rise of the Planet of the Apes_ was released on August 5, 2011, to critical
and commercial success. The film was nominated for an [Academy
Award](/wiki/Academy_Award "Academy Award") for [Best Visual
Effects](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Visual_Effects "Academy Award for Best
Visual Effects"). It was also nominated for five [Saturn
Awards](/wiki/Saturn_Awards "Saturn Awards") including [Best
Director](/wiki/Saturn_Award_for_Best_Director "Saturn Award for Best
Director") for Wyatt and [Best Writing](/wiki/Saturn_Award_for_Best_Writing
"Saturn Award for Best Writing") for Jaffa and Silver, winning [Best Science
Fiction Film](/wiki/Saturn_Award_for_Best_Science_Fiction_Film "Saturn Award
for Best Science Fiction Film"), [Best Supporting
Actor](/wiki/Saturn_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor "Saturn Award for Best
Supporting Actor") for Serkis and [Best Special
Effects](/wiki/Saturn_Award_for_Best_Special_Effects "Saturn Award for Best
Special Effects"). Serkis's performance as
[Caesar](/wiki/Caesar_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Caesar \(Planet of the Apes\)")
was widely acclaimed, earning him many nominations from associations which do
not usually recognize [performance capture](/wiki/Motion_capture "Motion
capture") as traditional acting. A sequel to the film, _[Dawn of the Planet of
the Apes](/wiki/Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Dawn of the Planet of the
Apes")_ , was released on July 11, 2014, and a third film, _[War for the
Planet of the Apes](/wiki/War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "War for the Planet
of the Apes")_ , was released on July 14, 2017.

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

Will Rodman, a [scientist](/wiki/Scientist "Scientist") at the [San
Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco") [biotech](/wiki/Biotechnology
"Biotechnology") company Gen-Sys, is testing the viral-based drug ALZ-112 on
[chimpanzees](/wiki/Common_chimpanzee "Common chimpanzee") to find a cure for
[Alzheimer's disease](/wiki/Alzheimer%27s_disease "Alzheimer's disease").
ALZ-112 is given to a chimp named Bright Eyes, greatly increasing her
intelligence. But then, during Will's presentation for the drug, Bright Eyes
is forced from her cage, goes on a rampage, and is shot to death. Will's boss
Steven Jacobs terminates the project and has the chimps slaughtered. However,
Will's assistant Robert Franklin discovers that the reason for Bright Eyes'
rampage was that she had recently given birth to an infant chimp. Will
reluctantly agrees to take in the chimp, who is named Caesar. Will learns that
Caesar has inherited his mother's intelligence and decides to raise him. Three
years later, Will introduces Caesar to the [redwood](/wiki/Redwood "Redwood")
forest at [Muir Woods National Monument](/wiki/Muir_Woods_National_Monument
"Muir Woods National Monument"). Meanwhile, Will treats his
[dementia](/wiki/Dementia "Dementia")-suffering father Charles with ALZ-112,
which seems to restore his cognitive ability.

Five years later, when Caesar reaches adolescence and sees a dog on a leash
like his own, he questions his identity and learns of his origins from Will.
Meanwhile, Charles's condition returns as he becomes resistant to ALZ-112.
Caesar injures a neighbor, Douglas Hunsiker, while defending a confused
Charles. As a result, he is placed in a primate shelter where he is tormented
by a chimp named Rocket and the chief guard, Dodge Landon, but also where he
befriends an [orangutan](/wiki/Orangutan "Orangutan") named Maurice who came
from a [circus](/wiki/Circus "Circus"). Caesar learns how to unlock his cage,
gaining free access to the common area. With the assistance of a
[gorilla](/wiki/Gorilla "Gorilla") named Buck, he confronts the sanctuary's
alpha, Rocket and claims that position. Meanwhile, Jacobs clears development
of a more powerful, gaseous version of the drug – ALZ-113 – when Will tells
him it can also improve intelligence. Will takes the drug home to try to save
his father, but Charles declines further treatment and dies overnight.

After attempting to test the drug on a scarred [bonobo](/wiki/Bonobo "Bonobo")
test subject named Koba, Franklin becomes exposed to ALZ-113 and becomes ill.
Attempting to warn Will at his home, he sneezes blood onto Hunsiker and is
later discovered dead. Will attempts to reclaim Caesar, but the chimp refuses
to go home with him so he could look after the other apes. Instead, he escapes
from the facility and returns to Will's house, where he takes canisters of the
ALZ-113. Upon returning, Caesar releases the gas and allows it to enhance the
intelligence of the other apes. When Dodge attempts to get him back into his
cage, Caesar speaks for the first time, yelling "No!" and gets in a fight
which inadvertently leads to Dodge's death. The apes flee the facility,
release the remaining chimps from Gen-Sys, and free more apes from the [San
Francisco Zoo](/wiki/San_Francisco_Zoo "San Francisco Zoo") on the way.

A battle ensues as the ape army fights their way past a police blockade on the
[Golden Gate Bridge](/wiki/Golden_Gate_Bridge "Golden Gate Bridge") to escape
into the redwood forest. Buck sacrifices himself to save Caesar by jumping
into the helicopter in which Jacobs is riding. The helicopter crashes onto the
bridge, trapping Jacobs in the wreckage. Koba seizes his chance for revenge
and sends Jacobs falling to his death in the bay below.

As the apes find their way into the forest, Will arrives and warns Caesar that
the humans will hunt them down, and begs him to return home. In response,
Caesar hugs him and says that, "Caesar is home." Will, realizing that this is
indeed their last goodbye, respects Caesar's wishes. The apes embrace their
new lifestyle in the forest.

In a [mid-credits scene](/wiki/Post-credits_scene "Post-credits scene"), an
infected Hunsiker leaves his house for work as an airline pilot, arriving at
[San Francisco International
Airport](/wiki/San_Francisco_International_Airport "San Francisco
International Airport") for his flight to [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris"). His
nose begins to drip [blood](/wiki/Blood "Blood") onto the floor. A graphic
traces the spread of the humanity-ravaging virus around the globe via
international flight routes.

##
Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

###
Humans[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Humans")]

  * [James Franco](/wiki/James_Franco "James Franco") as Dr. William "Will" Rodman, a [biologist](/wiki/Biologist "Biologist") who is trying to discover a cure for his father's [Alzheimer's disease](/wiki/Alzheimer%27s_disease "Alzheimer's disease") by testing ALZ-112 on chimps. He is a father figure to Caesar. James Franco was cast after talks with [Tobey Maguire](/wiki/Tobey_Maguire "Tobey Maguire") broke down.[7][8]
  * [Freida Pinto](/wiki/Freida_Pinto "Freida Pinto") as Caroline Aranha, a [primatologist](/wiki/Primatologist "Primatologist") who starts a relationship with Will and grows attached to Caesar.
  * [John Lithgow](/wiki/John_Lithgow "John Lithgow") as Charles Rodman, Will's Alzheimer's-afflicted father and a former music teacher who improves after Will gives him the ALZ-112 and forms a grandfatherly bond with Caesar.
  * [Brian Cox](/wiki/Brian_Cox_\(actor\) "Brian Cox \(actor\)") as John Landon, manager of the [San Bruno](/wiki/San_Bruno "San Bruno") Primate Shelter where Caesar is confined for a time. His full name is a reference to one of the astronauts in the original _[Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(1968_film\) "Planet of the Apes \(1968 film\)")_.
  * [Tom Felton](/wiki/Tom_Felton "Tom Felton") as Dodge Landon, John's son and an animal caretaker at the shelter, who abuses the apes for sport. His first and last name are references to two of the astronauts in the original _[Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(1968_film\) "Planet of the Apes \(1968 film\)")_.
  * [David Oyelowo](/wiki/David_Oyelowo "David Oyelowo") as Steven Jacobs, Will's arrogant boss. His last name is a reference to [Arthur P. Jacobs](/wiki/Arthur_P._Jacobs "Arthur P. Jacobs"), the producer of the original [_Planet of the Apes_ series](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes "Planet of the Apes").
  * [Tyler Labine](/wiki/Tyler_Labine "Tyler Labine") as Robert Franklin, a chimp handler at Gen-Sys and one of Will's friends. His surname is a reference to [Franklin Schaffner](/wiki/Franklin_Schaffner "Franklin Schaffner"), the director of the original film.
  * [Jamie Harris](/wiki/Jamie_Harris_\(actor\) "Jamie Harris \(actor\)") as Rodney, a caretaker and a nightwatchman who is much kinder to the apes at the sanctuary and is regularly mocked by Dodge for this.
  * [David Hewlett](/wiki/David_Hewlett "David Hewlett") as Douglas Hunsiker, Will's hot-headed neighbor.
  * [Chelah Horsdal](/wiki/Chelah_Horsdal "Chelah Horsdal") as Irena, a nurse who is looking after Charles.

###
Apes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Apes")]

  * [Andy Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis "Andy Serkis") as Caesar, a [common chimpanzee](/wiki/Common_chimpanzee "Common chimpanzee") whose intelligence is increased from inheriting ALZ-112 from his mother during her pregnancy, and who is raised by Will for eight years.
  * [Karin Konoval](/wiki/Karin_Konoval "Karin Konoval") as Maurice, a wise and benevolent [Bornean orangutan](/wiki/Bornean_orangutan "Bornean orangutan") who was retired from the circus and knows sign language; he becomes Caesar's closest ally. Konoval also cameos as the court clerk whom Will briefly argues with about his [appeal](/wiki/Appeal "Appeal"). His name is a reference to [Maurice Evans](/wiki/Maurice_Evans_\(actor\) "Maurice Evans \(actor\)") who portray [Dr. Zaius](/wiki/Dr._Zaius "Dr. Zaius") in the original Planet of the Apes.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * [Terry Notary](/wiki/Terry_Notary "Terry Notary") as Rocket, the dominant common chimpanzee at the ape sanctuary, until Caesar overthrows him. Notary also plays Bright Eyes, Caesar's mother who was captured in Africa.
  * [Richard Ridings](/wiki/Richard_Ridings "Richard Ridings") as Buck, a [Western lowland gorilla](/wiki/Western_lowland_gorilla "Western lowland gorilla") who pledges his allegiance to Caesar after he is freed by him.
  * [Devyn Dalton](/wiki/Devyn_Dalton "Devyn Dalton") as Cornelia, a female common chimpanzee in the ape sanctuary.
  * Jay Caputo as Alpha, the [dominant male](/wiki/Alpha_\(ethology\) "Alpha \(ethology\)") common chimpanzee of Bright Eyes' troop and Caesar's father.
  * Christopher Gordon as Koba, a scarred and aggressive [bonobo](/wiki/Bonobo "Bonobo") who has spent most of his life in laboratories and holds a grudge against humans.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Production")]

### Development and
writing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Development and writing")]

In 2006, screenwriter-producer Rick Jaffa was searching for a script idea. As
Jaffa searched a newspaper articles [clipping](/wiki/Clipping_\(publications\)
"Clipping \(publications\)"), one about [pet chimpanzees](/wiki/Pet_monkey
"Pet monkey") that become troublesome to their owners and heartbroken for not
adapting well to the human environment intrigued him. As Jaffa eventually
realized it fit the _Planet of the Apes_ series, he called his wife and
screenwriting partner Amanda Silver to express his ideas of such a chimpanzee
eventually starting the ape revolution, and then the couple started developing
the character of [Caesar](/wiki/Caesar_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Caesar \(Planet
of the Apes\)"). Jaffa indicated that "it's a reinvention" and if he had to
pick between calling it a prequel or a reboot he would say it is a reboot:
"It's a different story of who Caesar is, and how he came to be. So it's
really kind of hard to put a label on it. We are hopefully rebooting it." He
went on to say that "we tried really hard to create a story that would stand
on its own and yet also pay homage and honor the movies that came before
us."[9] Jaffa and Silver then wrote a script and sold it to Fox, producers of
the _Apes_ franchise. The script added other elements which the couple had
researched, such as genetic engineering.[10] Several tributes to specific
scenes, characters, and cast and crew from the previous _Apes_ film series
were added in the script. In particular, Caesar's treatment at the primate
sanctuary parallels [Taylor](/wiki/Taylor_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\)#Taylor
"Taylor \(Planet of the Apes\)")'s treatment as a captive in the original
film.[11][12]

In a segment of a video blog post, director [Rupert Wyatt](/wiki/Rupert_Wyatt
"Rupert Wyatt") commented on the originality of the plot: "This is part of the
mythology and it should be seen as that. It's not a continuation of the other
films; it's an original story. It does satisfy the people who enjoy those
films. The point of this film is to achieve that and to bring that fan base
into this film exactly like _[Batman Begins](/wiki/Batman_Begins "Batman
Begins")_."[6] In a 2009 interview, Wyatt said, "We've incorporated elements
from _[Conquest of the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Conquest_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Conquest of the Planet of the
Apes")_ , in terms of how the apes begin to revolt, but this is primarily a
prequel to the 1968 film...Caesar is a revolutionary figure who will be talked
about by his fellow apes for centuries...This is just the first step in the
evolution of the apes, and there's a lot more stories to tell after this. I
imagine the next film will be about the all-out war between the apes and
humans."[13] [Mark Bomback](/wiki/Mark_Bomback "Mark Bomback") did an
uncredited rewrite of the script.[14]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Filming")]

Filming began in July 2010 in [Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver "Vancouver"),
[British Columbia](/wiki/British_Columbia "British Columbia").[15] Filming
also happened in [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco"),
[California](/wiki/California "California") (the primary setting of the
film),[15] and around [Oahu](/wiki/Oahu "Oahu"), [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii
"Hawaii"), which doubled for the African jungle as the schedule and budget did
not allow for location shooting in Africa.[16]

### Visual
effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Visual effects")]

As the apes in _Rise_ were meant to be actual apes, the producers decided not
to use actors in ape suits. After considering real apes, instead [Weta
Digital](/wiki/Weta_Digital "Weta Digital") created the apes digitally in
almost every case through [performance capture](/wiki/Performance_capture
"Performance capture").[17] Advances in the technology allowed the use of
performance capture in an exterior environment, affording the film-makers the
freedom to shoot much of the film on location with other actors, as opposed to
the confines of a soundstage.[18][19] The main breakthrough was a camera that
enabled viewing the motion capture dots in daylight, employed mostly for the
Golden Gate Bridge battle. A maximum of six actors could have their movements
captured, with larger ape crowds using fully digital animals animated using
Weta's move library. The [Golden Gate Bridge](/wiki/Golden_Gate_Bridge "Golden
Gate Bridge") set used both a physical set which was extended digitally, and a
fully computer-generated model of the bridge that also included the ocean and
nearby hills.[20]

After shooting the actors playing humans interacting with others wearing the
motion capture suits, a clean plate was shot with actors for extra reference.
Actor-stuntman [Terry Notary](/wiki/Terry_Notary "Terry Notary") guided the
actors on realistic ape movement, while Weta studied the chimps in the
[Wellington Zoo](/wiki/Wellington_Zoo "Wellington Zoo") for reference. The
digital apes also received detailed models with skeletons, muscles and nerve
tissue layers for accurate animation. Cast models of apes' heads and limbs
helped the texture department replicate skin details such as wrinkles and
pores. Given the difference between human and chimpanzee facial muscles, the
animators tweaked the performance through a new facial muscle system adding
dynamics, ballistics, and secondary motion. As the silent performance required
expressive eyes, a new eye model was made to depict both greater accuracy in
muscle movement in and around the eyes, and also tears, [pupil
dilation](/wiki/Pupillary_response "Pupillary response"), and light
refraction.[17][21] While [Andy Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis "Andy Serkis") was
the primary performer for Caesar, as the effects team considered that at times
"Andy overcame the character," other motion capture team actors were also
used, especially [Devyn Dalton](/wiki/Devyn_Dalton "Devyn Dalton"), whose
height matched that of a chimpanzee. Along with that, they used Notary to play
Caesar in stunt-filled scenes such as the Golden Gate Bridge scene.[22]

###
Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Music")]

The score for the film was written by [Patrick Doyle](/wiki/Patrick_Doyle
"Patrick Doyle") and performed by the [Hollywood Studio
Symphony](/wiki/Hollywood_Studio_Symphony "Hollywood Studio Symphony")
conducted by [James Shearman](/wiki/James_Shearman "James Shearman").[23] The
main concern was to have the music help progress the plot in the scenes
without dialogue, for instance, conveying the emotions of Caesar's
relationships with Will and Charles. To turn the score into a "driving force
that keeps audiences paying attention," Doyle employed an African-American
chorus and focused on percussion and "low and deep" orchestra sounds. Doyle
collaborated closely with the sound department to make the music complement
the sound effects, including writing a recurring theme based on their
recording of a chimpanzee.[24]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Critical response")]

On review aggregator [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten
Tomatoes"), the film has an approval rating of 81% based on 252 reviews, with
an average rating of 7.1/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Led by
Rupert Wyatt's stylish direction, some impressive special effects, and a
mesmerizing performance by Andy Serkis, _Rise of the Planet of the Apes_
breathes unlikely new life into a long-running franchise."[25] Another review
aggregator, [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), gave the film a score
of 68 out of 100, based on 39 critics, indicating "generally favorable
reviews".[26]

[Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") gave the film 3 out of 4 stars
and praised the role of Caesar and [Andy Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis "Andy
Serkis") by stating it was a "wonderfully executed character" and "one never
knows exactly where the human ends and the effects begin, but Serkis and/or
Caesar gives the best performance in the movie."[27] Giving the film 5 out of
5 stars, Joe Neumaier of _[Daily News](/wiki/Daily_News_\(New_York\) "Daily
News \(New York\)")_ labelled _Rise of the Planet of the Apes_ as the summer's
best popcorn flick.[28] Nick Pinkerton of _[The Village
Voice](/wiki/The_Village_Voice "The Village Voice")_ wrote, "Caesar's prison
conversion to charismatic pan-ape revolutionist is near-silent filmmaking,
with simple and precise images illustrating Caesar's General-like divining of
personalities and his organization of a group from chaos to order."[29] Roger
Moore of _[Orlando Sentinel](/wiki/Orlando_Sentinel "Orlando Sentinel")_
wrote, "Audacious, violent and disquieting, "Rise of the Planet of the Apes"
is a summer sequel that's better than it has any right to be." He gave the
film 3.5 out of 4 stars.[30] [Manohla Dargis](/wiki/Manohla_Dargis "Manohla
Dargis") of _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York
Times")_ praised the film by saying, "Precisely the kind of summer diversion
that the studios have such a hard time making now. It's good, canny-dumb fun."
She also gave it 3.5 out of 4 stars.[31]

[Peter Travers](/wiki/Peter_Travers "Peter Travers") of _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ noted that the film has mixed
"twists lifted from 1972's _Conquest of the Planet of the Apes_ and 1999's
_[Deep Blue Sea](/wiki/Deep_Blue_Sea_\(1999_film\) "Deep Blue Sea \(1999
film\)")_ ".[32]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Box office")]

_Rise of the Planet of the Apes_ made its debut in the United States and
Canada on roughly 5,400 screens within 3,648 theaters.[33] It grossed
$19,534,699 on opening day and $54,806,191 in its entire opening weekend,
making it #1 for that weekend as well as the fourth-highest-grossing August
opening ever.[34] The film held on to the #1 spot in its second weekend,
dropping 49.2%, and grossing $27,832,307.[35] _Rise of the Planet of the Apes_
crossed the $150 million mark in the United States and Canada on its 26th day
of release. _[Entertainment Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment
Weekly")_ said that this was quite an accomplishment for the film since the
month of August is a difficult time for films to make money.[36]

The film ended its run at the box office on December 15, 2011, with a gross of
$176,760,185 in the U.S. and Canada as well as $305,040,864 internationally,
for a total of $481,801,049 worldwide.[1]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Home media")]

_Rise of the Planet of the Apes_ was released on [Blu-ray Disc](/wiki/Blu-
ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc"), [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD"), and [Digital

##
Sequels[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Sequels")]

Main articles: [Dawn of the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes")
and [War for the Planet of the Apes](/wiki/War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "War
for the Planet of the Apes")

Regarding the story setting up possible sequels, director [Rupert
Wyatt](/wiki/Rupert_Wyatt "Rupert Wyatt") commented: "I think we're ending
with certain questions, which is quite exciting. To me, I can think of all
sorts of sequels to this film, but this is just the beginning."[51]
Screenwriter and producer Rick Jaffa also stated that _Rise of the Planet of
the Apes_ would feature several clues as to future sequels: "I hope that we're
building a platform for future films. We're trying to plant a lot of the seeds
for a lot of the things you are talking about in terms of the different apes
and so forth."[6]

On May 31, 2012, 20th Century Fox announced that the sequel would be named
_[Dawn of the Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Dawn
of the Planet of the Apes")_.[52] Reports said that Wyatt was leaving the
sequel due to his concern that a May 2014 release date would not give him
enough time to properly make the film;[53] he was replaced by
_[Cloverfield](/wiki/Cloverfield "Cloverfield")_ director [Matt
Reeves](/wiki/Matt_Reeves "Matt Reeves").[54] Jaffa and Silver returned as
producers and to pen the screenplay, with rewrites from [Scott Z.
Burns](/wiki/Scott_Z._Burns "Scott Z. Burns")[55] and [Mark
Bomback](/wiki/Mark_Bomback "Mark Bomback").[14]

Taking place ten years after _Rise_ , _Dawn_ follows Caesar's growing nation
of evolved apes threatened by human survivors that put both sides in the brink
of war.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] Andy Serkis, Terry Notary and Karin Konoval reprised their roles as
Caesar, Rocket and Maurice.[56] James Franco returned as Will Rodman in a
"cameo via video".[57] [Judy Greer](/wiki/Judy_Greer "Judy Greer") and [Toby
Kebbell](/wiki/Toby_Kebbell "Toby Kebbell") replace [Devyn
Dalton](/wiki/Devyn_Dalton "Devyn Dalton") and Christopher Gordon as Cornelia
and Koba, respectively.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Filming of _Dawn of the Planet of the Apes_
started on North [Vancouver Island](/wiki/Vancouver_Island "Vancouver Island")
in April 2013.[58] The film was released July 11, 2014.

On January 6, 2014, 20th Century Fox announced a third installment with Reeves
returning to direct and co-write along with Bomback, with a planned July 2016
release.[59][60] In January 2015, Fox delayed the release to July 14,
2017.[61][62] On May 14, 2015, the title was given as _War of the Planet of
the Apes_ ,[63] later re-titled to _[War for the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "War for the Planet of the Apes")_.
